titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Edmund White Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Friday March 29, 2019 at 03:02

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Includes personal and professional correspondence, manuscripts, research files, biographical material, financial papers, photographs, slides, audio visual material, ephemera.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Acquired primarily from Edmund White by gift and purchase, 1991-2013.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Boxes 25, 34, 38, 41, 53, 61, 64, 80-81, and 96 (audiovisual materials): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
Boxes 54, 73, 82 (computer disks): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies of electronic files may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Edmund White Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Edmund White Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection received a basic level of processing in 2014, including rehousing and in some instances minimal organization. Various acquisitions associated with the collection have not been merged and organized as a whole. Each acquisition is described separately in the contents list below, identified by a unique call number and titled according to month and year of acquisition.

The finding aid for this collection is compiled from individual preliminary lists for each acquisition that were created at or around the time of receipt by the library. The preliminary lists were migrated to comply with current archival descriptive standards and merged into a single file in 2007-2008. As part of the migration, modifications were made to the formatting of individual lists; however, the content of the lists was neither modified nor verified.

As a rule, descriptive information found in the Collection Contents section is drawn in large part from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.

Former call numbers: Uncat MSS 23, Uncat MSS 124, Uncat ZA MS 190, Uncat MSS 198, Uncat MSS 203, Uncat ZA MS 240, Uncat ZA MS 287, Uncat ZA MS 292, Uncat ZA MS 308, Uncat ZA MS 405, Uncat ZA MS 416, Uncat ZA MS 439, Uncat ZA MS 465, Uncat ZA MS 520, Uncat MSS 560, Uncat ZA MS 577, Uncat ZA MS 590, Uncat MSS 735, Uncat MSS 778, Uncat MSS 913, Uncat Mss 999, Uncat Za File 336, Uncat Za File 372.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Edmund White Papers provide insight into the professional and personal life of Edmund White, an American novelist, memoirist, and essayist, and are comprised of correspondence, drafts of writings, research files, personal papers, financial papers, photographs, slides, audiovisual material, computer media, and ephemera.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into twenty-five groupings: I. July 1991 Acquisition. II. September 1991 Acquisition. III. May 1993 Acquisition. IV. August 1993 Acquisition. V. August 1993 Acquisition. VI. June 1994 Acquisition. VII. September 1994 Acquisition. VIII. December 1994 Acquisition. IX. April 1995 Acquisition. X. May 1995 Acquisition. XI. June 1995 Acquisition. XII. November 1995 Acquisition. XIII. December 1996 Acquisition. XIX. January 1997 Acquisition. XV. October 1998 Acquisition. XVI. October 1998 Acquisition. XVII. April 2001 Acquisition. XVIII. November 2001 Acquisition. XIX. September 2003 Acquisition. XX. December 2004 Acquisition. XXI. April 2005 Acquisition. XXII. December 2006 Acquisition. XXIII. November 2007 Acquisition. XXIV. January 2011 Acquisition. XXV. November 2013 Acquisition.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Edmund White on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 1991.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Series I, Correspondence
, contains alphabetically arranged correspondence, including a number of folders of letters from Delilah White. Other major correspondents include Alfred Corn, Christopher Cox, David Kalstone, Stanley Redfern, and Marilyn Schaefer.

Series II, Writings
, is contained in Boxes 3-19 and arranged alphabetically by title. It includes manuscripts and typescripts for The Beautiful Room is Empty , A Boy's Own Story , and Nocturne for the King of Naples , as well as manuscripts for several unpublished early works, among them "Private Disquisitions" and "An Amorous History of Youth." There are also manuscripts, typescripts and printed copies of many shorter works, articles, and reviews by White, as well as extensive research files for States of Desire.

Series III, Financial Papers
, fills Boxes 20-22 and contains cancelled checks, checkbooks, tax returns, and various bills and receipts. Box 23 houses Series IV, Clippings
, which is divided into two sections: "Interviews" and "Clippings about Edmund White." Series V, Personal Papers
, contains two folders of juvenilia, a diary, school papers, awards and memorabilia.
Photographs , Series VI, contains portraits of Edmund White, his family, and friends, and includes a Robert Mapplethorpe photograph of White with Truman Capote. Oversize material is located in Boxes 26-29.
Former call number: Uncat ZA MS 240.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into six series: Correspondence, Writings, Financial Papers, Clippings, Personal Papers, and Photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I, Correspondence , is arranged alphabetically by author. Unidentified correspondence is found at the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II, Writings , is arranged alphabetically by title with the exception of Reviews. Each title is identified by type of material.

did.materialspec: A time code runs through the video.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A handwritten letter, dated 1993-04-19, is included with the tape. It reads: Dear Ed - Well - here it is. I feel weird about it at this point, too close, my eyes are fried. Worked really hard on it this weekend. Didn't sleep Friday night - then Saturday when the edit was at last over went out w/ this new boyfriend: Abraham, 23, from Senegal (on parle francais, quoi!) so totally handsome! We are taking it slow - he told me his dick was "wild"! Dancing til 3, really romantic and nice. I am so fried though and really look like shit. So that all can wait. I hope he can come to the screening this Saturday. Man, I wish you guys could be there - it'd be great! Oh - I sent two because I thought before you left you could drop one to John [Seagliati] with a note, maybe that would work. Also - credits still need to be added - that will be fun to see. And - SECAM French version I'll send to Paris for Herbert to see ASAP. Sub-titling in English will be done this week in advance of the screening. Talk to you soon. Love, B P.S. I think the idea of having me speak to the camera during the credits about how I feel is a really good idea.
